Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: Living in a major city means my neighborhood is a melting pot of diverse communities. Residential areas are haphazardly interspersed with commercial sections, where a range of businesses operate, from offices to stores and entertainment spots. There's an abundance of new eateries and shops to explore, with both big-name corporations and quaint boutique stores lining the streets. Despite the hustle and bustle, a few parks are nearby where people stroll with their kids. Diversity is abundant, with a prominent LGBTQ+ community, Orthodox Jewish enclave, and former Soviet Union refugees and immigrants all within a small radius. Venturing beyond my immediate area reveals pockets of various ethnicities, such as Koreatown, Chinatown, and Little Armenia. But driving to these places can be a lengthy affair, even for a short 10-mile journey, thanks to the notorious traffic. Most people in the city prefer to drive, not walk, and parking is a challenge. Ironically, the city has seen a surge in construction, adding more apartment buildings. While it's attractive to new residents, many locals dread the increased population and traffic congestion. Housing options are varied, with single-family homes, duplexes, and apartments of different sizes. Even in my neighborhood, there's a mix of house types. People of all ages live here, and while it's not a tightly-knit community, I have fond childhood memories of playing with nearby neighbors.

My hood's a unique blend of old and new, with single-family homes and a few split units. My crib's got a tiny front yard and a driveway to the left. Reminds me of that not-so-distant past when suburban living was the American dream, but it's losing its shine. My neighbors and I still hold onto the dream, but the optimism's dwindling. Kids play in the streets, footballs at the ready, with cars stopping traffic. The old public school's been here forever, inspiring today's youth while stirring nostalgic memories in the elders. Churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are always packed. Houses look different but feel the same. There's a Yemeni-owned supermarket, "Super A," and most residents are African American. The streets are wide, and kids play football, pausing for passing cars. Lots of long-time residents, each with their own stories of the good ol' days. A former karate school turned into a pharmacy, because who needs martial arts when you can have pills? There's an old movie theatre that plays age-old flicks for cheap, attracting the elders but not the kids. We've got a nearby expressway, but we wanted an exit in our town. The youth wanted it, elders didn't. City council denied it, fearing it'd ruin the town. They're building a new high school, and we're deciding on a mascot. I reckon a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be the perfect rep for our town.

You might overlook it at first glance - it's behind a run-down shopping strip, not a place you'd guess there are places to live, and certainly not places most people would want to live. But if you walk past the old, abandoned Whole Foods and behind the hotels that only see life during summertime reunions, you'll find a hidden community. Nestled here are a few apartment complexes, lined up like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully taken apart and set in a row. The first ones you see have been in the news for some shady dealings, so let's skip them. But the ones beside and behind them are another world that hardly anyone in this area knows about. Across the road is a community college satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings where students shuffle in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 AM. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, much to the annoyance of commuters who shake their fists out the window. The road branches into another residential street, with a park and a rehab center on one side. The center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan that stirs the warm summer air. Kids run around the park, doing cartwheels and pinwheels, while bees lazily buzz in the flower patches. Older folks walk their dogs, scowling at skateboarders and nodding at the teenage girls by the playground, gossiping about boys and YouTube trends. A strip mall beside the park has a sushi place with cheap food, a swimming supply store, and a nail salon. You can fill your pool, get a manicure, and eat hibachi chicken all at once. There's also a DIY frozen yogurt place where teens clutch cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt while doing stunts on their skateboards and vaping. This neighborhood is a slice of old-school America - a piece of history in the slow-paced South where nothing much changes, not even time.

“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the endless sea of cornfields stretching towards the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing full well she’d be floored by the sheer openness of the landscape. She hailed from a town where the grocery store was a mere five-minute walk from her doorstep—she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Blindsided by the omnipresence of cornfields, I filled her in on what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood both my identity and my roots. Cruising down a winding two-lane country road, you’ll eventually reach a sprawling quarry filled with water. Just beyond it lies the small development I call home. The houses here are predominantly brick and stucco, each with at least a half-acre of land—a pride of ownership that everyone takes to heart. During springtime, the driveways are lined with the highest-end Mercedes-Benz luxury cars, gleaming under the midday sun after a thorough car wash. As we continued towards my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor, always with a cheerful smile, was out tending to his lawn. He spends the entire day mowing, his humming overpowering the mower’s noise. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a kick out of him, but he’s always genuine and has a fascinating past. He’s aged, losing some of his spark as the years went by. Underneath his cap, he was once a doctor and blends seamlessly with his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you’ll reach my home. The side yard is teeming with geese, chased by our Terrier. Out back, there’s a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear the bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from nearby farms. Crossing the handmade wooden bridge leads to an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This is where I spent most of my childhood—building tree forts, ‘hunting’ animals (mostly chasing them), and always finding a playmate among the neighborhood kids. Winters in my small town can be harsh, but there’s nothing more breathtaking. The green yard transforms into a vast, empty wilderness. Trees, once adorned with vibrant colors, become bare skeletons. Occasionally, a snowfall blankets the landscape, transforming it into a winter wonderland overnight. The backyard is filled with snow angels and snowmen crafted by my little sister, and during our winter wars, snowballs were our ammunition. We’d build massive igloo-like forts stocked with branches like a weapons arsenal. In our own little winter wonderland, we played pretend, free from the world’s cares. We were just kids, with nothing but laughter and imagination.

Portland, Oregon, is the epitome of "weirdness". Its unofficial motto, emblazoned on a building that's part pizza joint, bar, music venue, and strip club, reads "Keep Portland Weird". For some, it's a nod to Portland's past, a time when it was less known and cheaper, fostering a culture of creativity and uniqueness. For others, it's a call to come to a place where being weird is, dare I say, trendy. Despite an influx of wealthy Californians and the ever-present construction of condos, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't mean open-armed acceptance, but it does mean embracing the unconventional. Portland, like any other city, imports most of its goods from China and has its share of modern amenities and conflicts. We have yoga, hipsters, and business professionals, but perhaps our weirdness stems from taking all this with a grain of salt. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, houses are vibrant, home gardens are lush, and sidewalks host free boxes. These are cardboard or plastic receptacles filled with treasures for the wandering passerby. Clothes, books—who knows what you'll find? Portland's magic lies in its neighborhoods. That's my take, but Portland is filled with oddities galore. Some might scoff at the idea of browsing discarded clothes for fashion or go to yoga with goats or support the local soccer team, the Timbers. Portland is a hub of passions and aspirations, with some folks spending too much time at the bar dreaming of chasing their dreams. Yes, addiction is an issue. It's often linked to mental health struggles, and the perpetual rain and gloomy skies don't help. Homelessness is another challenge. Portland's social services attract the homeless, but they're insufficient. The non-homeless population is split between concern and resentment. In this, Portland is oddly normal.

The mountains stand sentinel in the north, testifying to the sun's daily dance of dawn and dusk. They're there, unwavering and unperturbed by life's ups and downs, even when I'm too busy to notice them. On those days when I'm at my most frazzled, they demand attention, and when I turn to them, they provide respite for my anxious soul, lending me the strength to trudge on, day by day. I first settled here for my undergrad, and the mountains north of campus were the first to captivate me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights, but it's the mountains that hold the crown. The rest of town is charming in its own right, with countless cafes that have been home to many caffeine-fueled study sessions. A short walk or bus ride takes you to the downtown area, where faded brick buildings and bustling restaurants give it a faded charm, echoing the vibrancy of its neighboring urban city. This mix of old and new, bustle and serenity, makes this town a fascinating place to explore and create cherished memories. Whether it's an all-nighter walk past the rusted swings in the park or a last-minute rush through downtown to catch a movie, the town offers a varied canvas for experiences. But it's also home to harsh memories, as all places are. The ponds, in particular, are a fitting place to reflect and even cry through existential crises, as I've done more times than I'd like to admit. Watching the pond's inhabitants go about their lives, I've often pondered my own sense of purpose. One day, as I walked past the pond and the park, towards the main street, the sun broke through the clouds, painting the sky with its rays and casting a golden glow over the palm trees. As I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north, and there they were, the mountains that have always been there. They loomed large against the sky, stirring in me a renewed sense of perseverance.

If you're planning to head to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you've got it made when it comes to getting there—public transportation is a cinch, and it's one of the most popular modes of transit in NYC. Bensonhurst is pretty urban, so you'll still feel like you're in the heart of the city. Asian stores are dotted throughout the neighborhood, with an influx of Asian inhabitants over the past two decades. You'll find an Asian-owned store on nearly every block, with supermarkets and laundromats being the most prevalent. Locals swear by the quality of food and the reasonable prices at these businesses—they're a godsend. Just around the corner from me, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes' walk of each other. But don't think Bensonhurst is all Asian—it's diverse, with immigrants and their offspring living side by side. The majority of big businesses are Asian-owned, and there's even a recently renovated park nearby with ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and a water fountain. Since it's New York, you know the parks will be diverse and welcoming to everyone. You won't find many corporate buildings here; most are co-op or condo apartments. Most residents live in two-family houses, and while the neighborhood is generally nice, it can be quite loud—cars blasting music and drivers flooring it can wake you up in the morning. Nighttime visitors should be cautious; while it's generally safe, folks can be unpredictable, and there are occasional incidents of trouble-making, bullying, and theft. I've personally been on the receiving end of physical assault and package theft in the past, although that was a while ago. Dog owners also tend to ignore the rule about cleaning up after their pets; you'll find dog waste on the streets every morning. My biggest peeve is walking through dog waste, so I keep my shoes clean!

My locale lacks sidewalks, and my dwelling sits atop the steepest incline, dubbed "work out hill" by nearby joggers. The main thoroughfare is pitted and weathered, with dangling wires and frequent repairs. Our region is damp, with constant rain and storms bringing down branches and power lines, leaving them in a patchwork state. Towering evergreens surround us, much to the displeasure of residents who see them as obstructions to ocean views. Houses are built high with large glass facades to catch the view, particularly at sunset when the water glows and the sky turns orange. But it's often overcast, with a haze obscuring the sun. Moss thrives on rooftops, cars, and railings, and even my car turned green from a month's neglect. Kids are scarce, replaced by dogs that roam, and rabbits that dig up lawns. My cats have taken care of most of the rabbit problem. Birdlife includes sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional hawks chased by crows. Though there are no shops, a few restaurants serve fresh seafood by the waterfront, where rocks make for decent skipping. The bay is narrow, often visible despite the mist.

I call my humble abode home in a picturesque southern Tennessee suburb. It's nestled at the intersection of two state highways, which means we get more than our fair share of traffic, but other than that, it's a peaceful neighborhood. The folks who live here are an eclectic bunch, and I've grown accustomed to most of them. Yard work and daily chores keep everyone busy, and in the winter, we can be found sledding down the hill on our side street. We're the lucky residents who live at the front corner, so we're always up to speed with the comings and goings of the neighborhood. Whenever we spot a strange vehicle, our antennae go up. Some folks take to the streets for exercise or to walk their dogs, while kids zoom around on their bikes. We're a family of four—myself, my lovely wife, and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen—and we're a regular fixture on the street. We make the most of our outdoor time, sometimes even braving the rain. BBQing on our back deck brings a delightful aroma to the air, and the sound of lawn mowers is a summertime staple. Our neighborhood is a veritable forest, with a plethora of trees and an abundance of leaves in the fall. Leaf-raking and leaf-burning become annual rituals, and the scent is a comforting herald of autumn's arrival. The winters here are mild, making it feel like a long fall. Our garage sits at the back, so we barely use the front door unless someone knocks, which is a rare occurrence. I spend my time working on my truck or other projects in the garage, and when the garage doors are open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are usually quiet around here, except for Thanksgiving and other visiting times when extra cars line the streets. All things considered, I'm content living here. If it weren't for the constant traffic, it would be idyllic.

My neighborhood is slap bang in the middle of the high desert, where there's dirt, dirt, and more dirt. If you haven't lived here, you can't truly understand the constant brown, and when you do see a lawn, it's clear that person's dropping serious cash on upkeep. Back in the 90s, houses were scattered far and wide out here, but now it's pretty much the same, with plenty of new additions. The place looks more and more like a city every day, but hey, that's the way things are going, right? Most of the neighbors are super friendly, but like any city, there are good parts and bad. In my hood, I'm surrounded by friendly old folks, so I guess it's a pretty nice neighborhood. The shops around here are mostly chain places like Food For Less and Smart and Final. If you want organic, you'll have to venture out. The most common jobs around here are construction, which makes sense since this city is still largely undeveloped. That's a bit scary for me; I left a big city and don't fancy going back. My full-time gig is as a drywall and T-bar installer, which is where I'm based. What I love about my home are the various critters. People come to the high desert for the stark beauty of the place. The desert's climate and terrain have created unique ecosystems that need protection and are home to all sorts of wildlife. To coexist safely, we humans should get to know our non-human neighbors. My kids and I have adapted well to the wildlife. Right now, my three kids are outside trying to catch lizards and desert bugs while I write. As for attractions, Victorville is a great spot for families to experience the desert. If you can, time your visit to coincide with the annual San Bernardino County Fair. It's a great mix of activities and fun. Plus, take a trip to nearby Wrightwood to see snow-capped mountains and enjoy some winter sports. If you're into natural history and culture, check out the Victor Valley Museum. It's packed with geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's development.

When someone asks about my 'hood, it's not like theirs, that's for sure. I mean, I ain't got no place to call my own like most folks do. My neighborhood's the campus I live on, and the folks in my dorm are my crew. The campus itself is my neighborhood too, but not as much. Still, it's got all the essentials - homes, people, stores, and parks. Let's dive into the homes first. There's apartments, actual houses, and dorms. Apartments usually house 2-4 people per room, with 4-6 rooms per floor, and most buildings have 2 floors, housing about 20 or so people. Houses are for alumni, but there's not many around. Then there's the dorms, where you'll find 100's of students living in rooms that house two people, with some exceptions. Most newer students and staff live in these, while older students and staff live in apartments.

Moving on to the people, diversity is my neighborhood's trademark. It's a mix of all ages and cultures, with staff in houses and newer students in dorms. The stores? You'll find all sorts of dining options, plus our school's unique clothing and grocery shops. And the park? It's a playground for all, kept clean and safe by everyone in the neighborhood.

Well, considering I've been here for a decade, I guess I can share what I've experienced. First off, I was pretty bummed when I first moved to this neighborhood. Coming from Riverdale to Stockbridge was a change, and I'm not gonna lie, I missed home and cried. But my folks had their reasons, and we moved for better housing, a better high school, and to leave behind the 'ghetto'. Over the years, I adapted, made new friends, and even enemies in school. I didn't really get to know my neighbors much, except for Mr. Glen and his family, and Dennis for a bit, who lived right next door. They've been great, almost like family. I remember attending Mr. Glen's remarriage, it was a blast. Ms. Veda's little white leg-strap was a horrific entrance, but I caught it! Sadly, I missed the bouquet. We danced the night away, and I enjoyed hanging with Marsharii, one of their daughters. Hope she's doing well now. The neighborhood's a maze, but with GPS, I can explore it now. I've only gone so far, and that's where I hang with Kason and Curtis. We'd play games and live life to the fullest. Sometimes I'd go to the park, enjoy nature, and practice balance with home depot sticks and my bokken. There's a basketball and tennis court too, though I haven't played in ages. My pops raised me and my bestie on tennis with Mr. Graves, and we'd have a blast. There's been plenty of fun times, and I believe the best is yet to come!

My pad is in the vicinity of the uni I attend, which is pretty swell as you can imagine. The housing mostly consists of apartment blocks, but there are a handful of eateries and taverns that are a blast to frequent and aren't breaking the bank. One joint just got a new name, and it's a bit pricier now, but the service and drinks are solid. The locals are a friendly bunch, mainly comprised of students and those with a lower income since the rent is fair. There's an elementary school a stone's throw away, so there are plenty of tykes around. I'm not really close with my neighbors, and that's just fine by me, as they're quite the pot heads. The building management found that out and placed an air freshener unit across from their door, which my partner and I thought was a hoot. The edifices in the area are mostly old but have had some sprucing up inside. Further down the road, there are some newbuilds, but I'm not a fan as I suspect the construction wasn't up to par. They're cheaply made but the rent is steep, which I think is a rip-off but they get away with it due to the campus proximity. There's a budget joint a few minutes' walk, serving up food on paper plates, most microwaved. Across the street is a gas station, not the best place to work, but the city gave it a makeover last summer with a broad sidewalk, lush greenery, and a tidier look. Our apartment block is wrapped in trees, though a few were chopped down, leaving behind a few stumps. Behind us is a tree line and another set of apartments. We're on 42nd Street, but 43rd just behind us isn't as pleasant. The sidewalks are in shambles and the buildings look rough. The trees are probably there to disguise the buildings' state. Crime has been an issue in the area, especially at an apartment complex on that street, but it's not just them. There are places across the street with similar issues. But I dig where I live—I can afford it and there are plenty of useful amenities nearby. Plus, the uni is within walking distance and there are two bus stops for easy access to the shops and downtown.

My neighborhood is a cul-de-sac lined with yellow duplexes, spaced out to look like individual houses with white porches and green metal roofs. Most neighbors are pals, and we often gather at the end of the driveway for a chat while the kids play. It's a throwback to simpler times in this tech-filled world. Surrounded by fields and trees with a blue sky and fluffy clouds, it's a peaceful haven. Tornado warnings have been popping up this season, and last night wasn't an exception. I found myself huddled in my bathtub with my purse and pillows, my little dog in my arms, while my bigger one barked nervously in the living room. The storm brought hail, and the road was steaming from the sudden temperature drop. The hail melted instantly on the hot pavement. After the storm, a double rainbow appeared, which I quickly snapped photos of to share. The neighborhood was quiet afterwards, but eventually, everyone returned from their hiding spots. Dinner was cooking as mothers and kids ventured outside. This place is a charming Southern gem for me, a transplant from NH to NC. I live in a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, and although the houses look alike, the interiors vary. I love strolling across the large field to the pond (not for swimming) where I've seen deer and heard the bullfrog sing in the morning. It's forty minutes from Charlotte, and I'm lucky to call this small community village my home. The surrounding farms have a rooster crowing each morning, and sometimes, I hear a donkey braying in the evening.

So, I rolled into this hood just before eighth grade kicked off. It was a rough go at making buddies at first, but I eventually hit it off with a couple of dudes – one lived two doors down, the other on my street. Both moved on, but the memories remain. The originals are still here, for the most part. My 'hood's pretty typical American suburban fare: two-story houses galore, kids playing every warm weekend, weekday silence. No issues with neighbors, no package snatching, and a park 'bout a minute away. Basketball, football, and baseball memories (including a nasty elbow to the nose) are etched in there. Now, it's my cousin’s kids who make the park their playground, filling it with giggles and excitement. The park is pure nostalgia now. This hood's diverse, food-wise – Chinese, Indian, Mexican, Italian – all within a mile or so. GrubHub and DoorDash are the norm these days, but there's a heap of pizza joints too. Stores have everything you need, from dry cleaners to CVS and Walgreens, and even an Indian store for those midwestern tastes. I'm a fan of my 'hood, and reading about other folks' horror stories makes me damned grateful for mine.

My town, Johnston, is a sleepy little number nestled in South Carolina. It's not the flashiest or most unique place, but it stands tall in the agribusiness world as the Peach Capital of the World. The sign at the entrance makes that clear, and the farmland stretching out in every direction is a testament to that. Houses here are scattered, often standing two stories high with either metal or gray shingle roofs to keep cool in the summer. The main drag is home to the town's essentials: a one-stop light, three little eateries (Chinese, Mexican, and a burger joint), a pharmacy that's famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola, an expensive grocery store, a Dollar General that's always bustling, a furniture store with delivery service, a pet groomer, and a pair of clinics for human and animal health. The town doesn't boast much in terms of entertainment, with no parks, theaters, or bowling alleys. But Johnston Elementary School is a highlight, and the town is working on adding a recreational area to keep families and potential residents happy. It's a simple place, but that's part of its charm. You could easily miss it if you blink!

My first introduction to this city was through a podcast about vanished locals. The price tags for apartments were sky-high, way over a grand a month. None of my friends or I had heard about this before. I guess it's the struggle that keeps us going. Most nights, my buddies and I just end up bawling our eyes out. But we've had to adapt to the cost of living, learning to love the faint scent of dusty thrift store finds. It's the smell of adulthood, the one that lingers even after you've washed it off your clothes. Around here, there's a trio of thrift shops within walking distance. If you start on the far end, you can hit up two charity stores, a library, a rare bookshop, and a curiosity shop. Downtown's bustling, with cars and folks flooding the streets every morning, but inside the thrifts, it's always dead silent. It's a perfect spot to lose hours. This city's on the rise, they say. It's the headquarters for one of the world's biggest e-commerce giants, still feeling its growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone here has their own game plan, and no one particularly cares what you're up to. You can retreat into your shell, and the city will just keep on rolling like the tide. It's a lively place to be. Neighbors play music next door and sing upstairs, there's always some sort of event. It's a community of friends, not just a bunch of strangers. We come together for essentials, birthdays, funerals, and mutual aid. I'm grateful to be here. Most of my neighbors are cool, and they're kind too. I leave food, bring mail, and they do the same. It's a nice routine. Despite living in a vast, faceless modernist sprawl, it's the people like my neighbors who make me feel like I haven't lost my mind.

The hood I'm from is your classic cookie-cutter 'burb. The neighborhood association here is nuts about uniformity. First thing you'll notice is the uniformity of the homes - all single-family, well-maintained, and with two-car garages. Front yards are all identical with a patch of grass, decorative pebbles, and short driveways. Trees are here and there too. The streets are immaculate with no potholes to be seen. Most of the homes are single-story, but you'll occasionally spot a two-story joint. No individual mailboxes here; it's more like an apartment complex. Everyone uses a key to access their mailbox, and there are big lockers for packages. I'm at the edge of the city, so it's half rural, half 'burb. Lots of land means multiple community pools and walking trails. The neighborhood is mostly made up of retired folks, but there's a mix of middle-age and young professionals too. The city is big by population but has a small-town feel. We've got all the amenities you'd expect - like a mall, high-end groceries, and bargain outlets. It takes about 15 minutes to get anywhere significant, and then there's plenty to choose from. It's safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We've got pools, walking trails, and while we're not super close to shopping, a car ride away gets you to any major chain you'd like.

I'm based in a small Midwestern town that's nestled just outside the sprawling suburbs of a big city. The east side of my neighborhood, where I reside, is the most economically challenged area. Most houses here are rented or owned by low-income folks, but it's not all that unpleasant. My neighbors here are generally friendly, giving a nod and a smile when I'm out. Crime rates are a bit higher in comparison to other parts of town, with a few violent incidents in recent years, including a shooting outside an area bar that took the life of our next-door neighbor's son. Fortunately, my family has escaped these incidents unscathed, apart from some minor thefts from our porch. Our town has been heavily impacted by the opioid epidemic, which has claimed many lives due to fentanyl overdoses. However, we have several addiction centers and Narcan training sessions to help combat this issue. Despite these challenges, there are plenty of positives. My son's elementary school is top-notch, with a supportive staff who have made his special needs journey smooth and bully-free. The PTO there has organized numerous family events, and the school offers free breakfast and lunch to all students. The City Council has made improvements, but they've mainly been on the west side where the shopping areas are. While this has left my east side feeling slightly neglected, the overall quality of life is good. I've lived here for over 16 years and can't imagine myself anywhere else.

My neighborhood is a treasure trove of culture. Perched on a hill, it's surrounded by buildings that carry historical weight, and I live in a 7-story apartment block directly across from an old live theater. Just a block down the Hill is a quaint arcade bar that attracts various types of folks on warm summer nights. Lines of people often form outside this spot, especially during weekends in June and July. A few blocks up is a substantial city park. Though it's centrally located, it's surprisingly big for the area it inhabits. The park is ringed by concrete steps, and during winter, homeless individuals set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and steps, as rain is more common than snow in these parts. They huddle close together for warmth and are conveniently within reach of the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I adore about my city is the people themselves. Hilltop was once notorious for gang violence, and tales of the government's attempts to clean the streets are still told today. These stories echo through the generations, even among transplants like me. The residents work hard to keep their 'hood clean and are vigilant about what happens in their city. They say, "If you're white, don't walk the Hill at night." This caution may stem from the past, and it's tinged with social conditioning. Perhaps it's my dark enough skin that I pass as not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop sees me as one of their own, someone deeply aware of the reminders of racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions that haunt our nation. I know one thing—no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, greeted by people who've offered me jackets rather than trouble. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open late for me to charge my phone, and where I've waited, feeling invisible, against concrete storefronts on the bleakest nights, only to receive a $5 from a stranger who told me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I call Rural America my home, specifically in small town Michigan. The drive from farmland to tourist cities is a common sight. Forget about big city malls, Wal-marts, Targets, or Applebee’s, here you drive if you need to go anywhere. But let me tell you, I live in one of the most breathtaking places on Earth, surrounded by water. Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix are my neighbors, and you can find a beach to dip your toes in everywhere you go. My neighborhood embodies the heart of small town living. Houses aren’t stacked, cookie-cutter, or new. They’re older, some updated, others with aluminum siding. Full basements line the streets, and yards boast trampolines, playsets, gardens, and fences for animals. Middle America's spirit is alive here, with hardworking folks raising families. Kids play freely in the streets, and neighbors know their neighbors. Lawns are well-maintained, with no leaves piled up from fall. It's a peaceful, safe haven, and while it's not flashy, it's exceptional in representing what people yearn for. The county sheriff's department and jail are nearby, as is the health department and recycling center. Baseball and softball fields are close by, with the small town airport nearby. You can hear small engine planes buzzing overhead. Ice cream from the local shop is a walk away, and downtown is just a bike ride or walk from our neighborhood. My kids ride their bikes to the park just a few blocks away. It's a fantastic place to call home.
